name: Amisulpride
summary: An atypical antipsychotic used for schizophrenia and, at lower doses, for dysthymia in some countries.
description: Amisulpride is a substituted benzamide atypical antipsychotic that selectively antagonizes dopamine D2 and D3 receptors. It is indicated for the treatment of acute and chronic schizophrenia and is notable for its dose-dependent pharmacology: at high doses, it blocks postsynaptic receptors to reduce positive symptoms; at low doses, it blocks presynaptic autoreceptors to enhance dopamine release and improve negative symptoms or dysthymia. It is not approved in the United States but is used in several European and other markets.

sections.text: Selectively blocks dopamine D2 and D3 receptors. At high doses, antagonizes postsynaptic receptors, reducing positive symptoms. At low doses, blocks presynaptic autoreceptors, enhancing dopamine release to improve negative symptoms and mood.

adult.start: 400–800 mg/day in divided doses for schizophrenia
adult.titrate: Adjust by clinical response; lower doses (50–300 mg/day) for negative symptoms or dysthymia

sections.geriatric: Start at the lower end of dosing range; monitor for QT prolongation
sections.hepatic_impairment: No adjustment necessary; minimal hepatic metabolism
sections.renal_impairment: Reduce dose in moderate/severe impairment (CrCl < 60 mL/min)

sections.text: Improvement in acute psychosis may be seen in 1–2 weeks; full response often takes 4–6 weeks or longer.

items: ECG at baseline and periodically if risk factors

sections.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh potential risks.
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; not recommended while breastfeeding.
sections.pediatrics: Not approved for pediatric schizophrenia in most regions.
sections.geriatrics: Higher QT prolongation risk; start low and monitor.

sections.text: Gradual dose reduction over at least 1–2 weeks to minimize withdrawal or rebound symptoms.

items: Minimal hepatic metabolism, making it safer in liver impairment.
Low-dose amisulpride is used in some countries for dysthymia.
Has a favorable metabolic profile compared to some atypicals, but prolactin elevation is common.
